comment._content: Is this her singing? youtu.be/EwMblYM29Kc youtu.be/0nE6C9Qo2Rc en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pack_Up_Your_Troubles_in_Your_Old_K... youtu.be/J0kDfQJheic

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: If it's not the singer Helen (Price) Clark, it might be Helen Converse Clark (1892-), who married Henry Carrington Lancaster in June 1913. Helen Converse Clark's father John Bates Clark (1847-1938) was a prominent economist at Columbia University. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Bates_Clark Helen Converse Clark's brother was also a prominent economist, John Maurice Clark (1884-1963): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Maurice_Clark Henry Carrington Lancaster (1882-1954) was a professor too, teaching French Literature at Amherst College (and later at Johns Hopkins). They had five children together. ead.library.jhu.edu/ms083.xml

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Maybe this could be of help: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=helen+clark&st=gallery Could she be the one on the right? lcweb2.loc.gov/service/pnp/ggbain/21400/21478v.jpg

comment.author: 21175765@N03
comment._content: Beautiful light and such a lovely model.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Well now I think the LOC has photos of several Helen Clarks!  There are at least two different Helen Clarks in that array, to my eye--definitely different profiles.  The one with very tightly waved hair and more prominent nose seems to be the singer (Helen Price Clark), because she's shown with a microphone at one point; the one on this page is the other one.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: It looks like most pictures are of the prominent-nosed singer? Which would make sense because Helen Converse Clark would be someone who only appears in the society pages on occasions like engagement, wedding, and divorce due to her prominent relations.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: I agree--and this photo does look like a society portrait.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Unfortunately, it was such a common name it will probably be impossible to identify her unless a relative sees this. The date on the negative is March, 1915, so maybe she was part of the social season that year.

comment._content: wow! I love this vintage mood!

comment._content: artolog: Thanks for bringing the date to our attention.  We include it in the description next time we update.

comment._content: William Bullock Clark had a daughter named Helen who was a debutante in Baltimore in 1915 according to news.google.com (sadly the links are all behind a paywall). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Bullock_Clark
